title: Elasticity and Its Application

questions.question: In general, elasticity is a measure of
options: the extent to which advances in technology are adopted by producers.
the extent to which a market is competitive.
how firms' profits respond to changes in market prices.
how much buyers and sellers respond to changes in market conditions.
questions.answer: how much buyers and sellers respond to changes in market conditions.

questions.question: Elasticity is
options: a measure of how much buyers and sellers respond to changes in market conditions.
the study of how the allocation of resources affects economic well-being.
the maximum amount that a buyer will pay for a good.
the value of everything a seller must give up to produce a good.
questions.answer: a measure of how much buyers and sellers respond to changes in market conditions.

questions.question: When studying how some event or policy affects a market, elasticity provides information on the
options: equity effects on the market by identifying the winners and losers.
magnitude of the effect on the market.
speed of adjustment of the market in response to the event or policy.
number of market participants who are directly affected by the event or policy.
questions.answer: magnitude of the effect on the market.

questions.question: When studying how some event or policy affects a market, elasticity provides information on the
options: government expenditures associated with the policy.
costs and benefits of the effect.
allocative efficiency of the effect.
direction and magnitude of the effect.
questions.answer: direction and magnitude of the effect.

questions.question: How does the concept of elasticity allow us to improve upon our understanding of supply and demand?
options: Elasticity allows us to analyze supply and demand with greater precision than would be the case in the absence of the elasticity concept.
Elasticity provides us with a better rationale for statements such as "an increase in x will lead to a decrease in y" than we would have in the absence of the elasticity concept.
Without elasticity, we would not be able to address the direction in which price is likely to move in response to a surplus or a shortage.
Without elasticity, it is very difficult to assess the degree of competition within a market.
questions.answer: Elasticity allows us to analyze supply and demand with greater precision than would be the case in the absence of the elasticity concept.

questions.question: When consumers face rising gasoline prices, they typically
options: reduce their quantity demanded more in the long run than in the short run.
reduce their quantity demanded more in the short run than in the long run.
do not reduce their quantity demanded in the short run or the long run.
increase their quantity demanded in the short run but reduce their quantity demanded in the long run.
questions.answer: reduce their quantity demanded more in the long run than in the short run.

questions.question: A 10 percent increase in gasoline prices reduces gasoline consumption by about
options: 6 percent after one year and 2.5 percent after five years.
2.5 percent after one year and 6 percent after five years.
10 percent after one year and 20 percent after five years.
0 percent after one year and 1 percent after five years.
questions.answer: 2.5 percent after one year and 6 percent after five years.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the consumers' responses to rising gasoline prices is correct?
options: About 10 percent of the long-run reduction in quantity demanded arises because people drive less and about 90 percent arises because they switch to more fuel-efficient cars.
About 90 percent of the long-run reduction in quantity demanded arises because people drive less and about 10 percent arises because they switch to more fuel-efficient cars.
About half of the long-run reduction in quantity demanded arises because people drive less and about half arises because they switch to more fuel-efficient cars.
Because gasoline is a necessity, consumers do not decrease their quantity demanded in either the short run or the long run.
questions.answer: About half of the long-run reduction in quantity demanded arises because people drive less and about half arises because they switch to more fuel-efficient cars.

questions.question: The price elasticity of demand measures how much
options: quantity demanded responds to a change in price.
quantity demanded responds to a change in income.
price responds to a change in demand.
demand responds to a change in supply.
questions.answer: quantity demanded responds to a change in price.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-5. Using the midpoint method, when income equals $7,500, what is the price elasticity of demand between $16 and $20?
The price elasticity of demand measures
options: buyers' responsiveness to a change in the price of a good.
the extent to which demand increases as additional buyers enter the market.
how much more of a good consumers will demand when incomes rise.
the movement along a supply curve when there is a change in demand.
questions.answer: buyers' responsiveness to a change in the price of a good.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-5. Using the midpoint method, when income equals $5,000, what is the price elasticity of demand between $8 and $12?
The price elasticity of demand for a good measures the willingness of
options: consumers to buy less of the good as price rises.
consumers to avoid monopolistic markets in favor of competitive markets.
firms to produce more of a good as price rises.
firms to respond to the tastes of consumers.
questions.answer: consumers to buy less of the good as price rises.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-5. Using the midpoint method, at a price of $16, what is the income elasticity of demand when income rises from $5,000 to $10,000?
Which of the following statements about the price elasticity of demand is correct?
options: The price elasticity of demand for a good measures the willingness of buyers of the good to buy less of the good as its price increases.
Price elasticity of demand reflects the many economic, psychological, and social forces that shape consumer tastes.
Other things equal, if good x has close substitutes and good y does not have close substitutes, then the demand for good x will be more elastic than the demand for good y.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-5. Using the midpoint method, at a price of $8, what is the income elasticity of demand when income rises from $7,500 to $10,000?
If the price of natural gas rises, when is the price elasticity of demand likely to be the highest?
options: immediately after the price increase
one month after the price increase
three months after the price increase
one year after the price increase
questions.answer: one year after the price increase

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-5. Using the midpoint method, at a price of $12, what is the income elasticity of demand when income rises from $5,000 to $10,000?
If the price of gasoline rises, when is the price elasticity of demand likely to be the highest?
options: immediately after the price increases
one month after the price increase
three months after the price increase
one year after the price increase
questions.answer: one year after the price increase

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-6. Using the midpoint method, what is the income elasticity of demand for good X?
If the price of milk rises, when is the price elasticity of demand likely to be the lowest?
options: immediately after the price increase
one month after the price increase
three months after the price increase
one year after the price increase
questions.answer: immediately after the price increase

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-6. Using the midpoint method, the income elasticity of demand for good Y is
options: 2.33, and good Y is a normal good.
-2.33, and good Y is an inferior good.
-0.43, and good Y is a normal good.
-0.43, and good Y is an inferior good.
questions.answer: -2.33, and good Y is an inferior good.

questions.question: Holding all other forces constant, when the price of gasoline rises, the number of gallons of gasoline demanded would fall substantially over a ten-year period because
options: buyers tend to be much less sensitive to a change in price when given more time to react.
buyers tend to be much more sensitive to a change in price when given more time to react.
buyers will have substantially more real income over a ten-year period.
the quantity supplied of gasoline increases very little in response to an increase in the price of gasoline.
questions.answer: buyers tend to be much more sensitive to a change in price when given more time to react.

questions.question: Last year, Shelley bought 6 pairs of designer jeans when her income was $40,000. This year, her income is $50,000, and she purchased 10 pairs of designer jeans. Holding other factors constant, it follows that Shelley
options: considers designer jeans to be a necessity.
considers designer jeans to be an inferior good.
considers designer jeans to be a normal good.
has a low price elasticity of demand for jeans.
questions.answer: considers designer jeans to be a normal good.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a determinant of the price elasticity of demand for a good?
options: the time horizon
the steepness or flatness of the supply curve for the good
the definition of the market for the good
the availability of substitutes for the good
questions.answer: the steepness or flatness of the supply curve for the good

questions.question: Last year, Carolyn bought 6 pairs of earrings when her income was $40,000. This year, her income is $52,000, and she purchased 7 pairs of earrings. Holding other factors constant, it follows that Carolyn's income elasticity of demand is about
options: 0.59, and Carolyn regards earrings as an inferior good.
0.59, and Carolyn regards earrings as a normal good.
1.7, and Carolyn regards earrings as an inferior good.
1.7, and Carolyn regards earrings as a normal good.
questions.answer: 0.59, and Carolyn regards earrings as a normal good.

questions.question: The greater the price elasticity of demand, the
options: more likely the product is a necessity.
smaller the responsiveness of quantity demanded to a change in price.
greater the percentage change in price over the percentage change in quantity demanded.
greater the responsiveness of quantity demanded to a change in price.
questions.answer: greater the responsiveness of quantity demanded to a change in price.

questions.question: Necessities such as food and clothing tend to have
options: high price elasticities of demand and high income elasticities of demand.
high price elasticities of demand and low income elasticities of demand.
low price elasticities of demand and high income elasticities of demand.
low price elasticities of demand and low income elasticities of demand.
questions.answer: low price elasticities of demand and low income elasticities of demand.

questions.question: Whether a good is a luxury or necessity depends on the
options: price of the good.
preferences of the buyer.
intrinsic properties of the good.
scarcity of the good.
questions.answer: preferences of the buyer.

questions.question: Income elasticity of demand measures how
options: the quantity demanded changes as consumer income changes.
consumer purchasing power is affected by a change in the price of a good.
the price of a good is affected when there is a change in consumer income.
many units of a good a consumer can buy given a certain income level.
questions.answer: the quantity demanded changes as consumer income changes.

questions.question: The price elasticity of demand for bread
options: is computed as the percentage change in quantity demanded of bread divided by the percentage change in price of bread.
depends, in part, on the availability of close substitutes for bread.
reflects the many economic, social, and psychological forces that influence consumers' tastes for bread.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: Danita rescues dogs from her local animal shelter. When Danita's income rises by 7 percent, her quantity demanded of dog biscuits increases by 12 percent. For Danita, the income elasticity of demand for dog biscuits is
options: negative, and dog biscuits are a normal good.
negative, and dog biscuits are an inferior good.
positive, and dog biscuits are an inferior good.
positive, and dog biscuits are a normal good.
questions.answer: positive, and dog biscuits are a normal good.

questions.question: The price elasticity of demand for eggs
options: is computed as the percentage change in quantity demanded of eggs divided by the percentage change in price of eggs.
will be lower if there is a new invention that is a close substitute for eggs.
will be higher if consumers consider eggs to be a necessity.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: is computed as the percentage change in quantity demanded of eggs divided by the percentage change in price of eggs.

questions.question: For which of the following goods is the income elasticity of demand likely highest?
options: water
diamonds
hamburgers
housing
questions.answer: diamonds

questions.question: The price elasticity of demand measures the
options: magnitude of the response in quantity demanded to a change in price.
direction of the shift in the demand curve in response to a market event.
size of the shortage created by the increase in demand.
responsiveness of quantity demanded to a change in income.
questions.answer: magnitude of the response in quantity demanded to a change in price.

questions.question: For which of the following goods is the income elasticity of demand likely highest?
options: natural gas
doctor's visits
hamburgers
boats
questions.answer: boats

questions.question: If the price of walnuts rises, many people would switch from consuming walnuts to consuming pecans. But if the price of salt rises, people would have difficulty purchasing something to use in its place. These examples illustrate the importance of
options: the availability of close substitutes in determining the price elasticity of demand.
a necessity versus a luxury in determining the price elasticity of demand.
the definition of a market in determining the price elasticity of demand.
the time horizon in determining the price elasticity of demand.
questions.answer: the availability of close substitutes in determining the price elasticity of demand.

questions.question: For which of the following goods is the income elasticity of demand likely lowest?
options: subscriptions to premium movie channels through the local cable television provider
hi-definition DVD players
champagne
housing
questions.answer: housing

questions.question: Suppose that Jane enjoys Diet Coke so much that she consumes one can every day. Although she enjoys gourmet cheese, she consumes it sporadically. If the price of Diet Coke rises, Jane decreases her consumption by only a very small amount. But if the price of gourmet cheese rises, Jane decreases her consumption by a lot. These examples illustrate the importance of
options: the availability of close substitutes in determining the price elasticity of demand.
a necessity versus a luxury in determining the price elasticity of demand.
the definition of a market in determining the price elasticity of demand.
the time horizon in determining the price elasticity of demand.
questions.answer: a necessity versus a luxury in determining the price elasticity of demand.

questions.question: For which of the following goods is the income elasticity of demand likely lowest?
options: water
sapphire pendant necklaces
filet mignon steaks
fresh fruit
questions.answer: water

questions.question: Suppose that Juan Carlos is filling out a survey that he received in the mail. The survey asks him what he would do if the price of his favorite toothpaste increased. Juan Carlos reports that he would switch to a different brand. The survey asks what he would do if the price of all toothpastes increased. Juan Carlos reports that he must use toothpaste, so he would have to adjust his spending elsewhere. These examples illustrate the importance of
options: changes in total revenue in determining the price elasticity of demand.
a necessity versus a luxury in determining the price elasticity of demand.
the definition of a market in determining the price elasticity of demand.
the time horizon in determining the price elasticity of demand.
questions.answer: the definition of a market in determining the price elasticity of demand.

questions.question: Last year, Joan bought 50 pounds of hamburger when her household's income was $40,000. This year, her household income was only $30,000 and Joan bought 60 pounds of hamburger. All else constant, Joan's income elasticity of demand for hamburger is
options: positive, so Joan considers hamburger to be an inferior good.
positive, so Joan considers hamburger to be a normal good and a necessity.
negative, so Joan considers hamburger to be an inferior good.
negative, so Joan considers hamburger to be a normal good but not a necessity.
questions.answer: negative, so Joan considers hamburger to be an inferior good.

questions.question: Suppose that gasoline prices increase dramatically this month. Lola commutes 100 miles to work each weekday. Over the next few months, Lola drives less on the weekends to try to save money. Within the year, she sells her home and purchases one only 10 miles from her place of employment. These examples illustrate the importance of
options: the availability of substitutes in determining the price elasticity of demand.
a necessity versus a luxury in determining the price elasticity of demand.
the definition of a market in determining the price elasticity of demand.
the time horizon in determining the price elasticity of demand.
questions.answer: the time horizon in determining the price elasticity of demand.

questions.question: If an increase in income results in a decrease in the quantity demanded of a good, then for that good, the
options: cross-price elasticity of demand is negative.
price elasticity of demand is elastic.
income elasticity of demand is negative.
income elasticity of demand is positive.
questions.answer: income elasticity of demand is negative.

questions.question: Economists compute the price elasticity of demand as the
options: percentage change in price divided by the percentage change in quantity demanded.
change in quantity demanded divided by the change in the price.
percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in price.
percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in income.
questions.answer: percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in price.

questions.question: To determine whether a good is considered normal or inferior, one could examine the value of the
options: income elasticity of demand for that good.
price elasticity of demand for that good.
price elasticity of supply for that good.
cross-price elasticity of demand for that good.
questions.answer: income elasticity of demand for that good.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-1. Which of the following is consistent with the elasticities given in Table 5-2?
options: A is a luxury, and B is a necessity.
A is a good several years after a price increase, and B is that same good several days after the price increase.
A is a Kit Kat bar, and B is candy.
A has fewer substitutes than B.
questions.answer: A has fewer substitutes than B.

questions.question: You and your college roommate eat three packages of Ramen noodles each week. After graduation last month, both of you were hired at several times your college income. You still enjoy Ramen noodles very much and buy even more, but your roommate plans to buy fewer Ramen noodles in favor of foods she prefers more. When looking at income elasticity of demand for Ramen noodles, yours would
options: be negative, and your roommate's would be positive.
be positive, and your roommate's would be negative.
be zero, and your roommate's would approach infinity.
approach infinity, and your roommate's would be zero.
questions.answer: be positive, and your roommate's would be negative.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-1. Which of the following is consistent with the elasticities given in Table 5-2?
options: A is grapes, and B is fruit.
A is T-shirts, and B is socks.
A is train tickets before cars were invented, and B is train tickets after cars were invented.
A is diamond necklaces, and B is beds.
questions.answer: A is train tickets before cars were invented, and B is train tickets after cars were invented.

questions.question: You and your college roommate eat three packages of Ramen noodles each week. After graduation last month, both of you were hired at several times your college income. Your roommate still enjoys Ramen noodles very much and buys even more, but you plan to buy fewer Ramen noodles in favor of foods you prefer more. When looking at income elasticity of demand for Ramen noodles, yours would
options: be negative and your roommate's would be positive.
be positive and your roommate's would be negative.
be zero and your roommate's would approach infinity.
approach infinity and your roommate's would be zero.
questions.answer: be negative and your roommate's would be positive.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-1. Which of the following is consistent with the elasticities given in Table 5-2?
options: A is root beer, and B is carbonated beverages.
A is bicycles, and B is mopeds.
A is airline tickets in the short run, and B is airline tickets in the long run.
A is gourmet coffee, and B is dentist's visits.
questions.answer: A is airline tickets in the short run, and B is airline tickets in the long run.

questions.question: Suppose good X has a negative income elasticity of demand. This implies that good X is
options: a normal good.
a necessity.
an inferior good.
a luxury.
questions.answer: an inferior good.

questions.question: Suppose there is a 6 percent increase in the price of good X and a resulting 6 percent decrease in the quantity of X demanded. Price elasticity of demand for X is
Suppose good X has a positive income elasticity of demand. This implies that good X could be (i) a normal good. (ii) a necessity. (iii) an inferior good. (iv) a luxury.
options: (i) only
(i) and (ii) only
(i), (ii), and (iv) only
(iii) only
questions.answer: (i), (ii), and (iv) only

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 4.0, then a 10 percent increase in price results in a
options: 0.4 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
2.5 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
4 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
40 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: 40 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.

questions.question: For which of the following types of goods would the income elasticity of demand be positive and relatively large?
options: all inferior goods
all normal goods
goods for which there are many complements
luxuries
questions.answer: luxuries

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 10.0, then a 4 percent increase in price results in a
options: 0.4 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
2.5 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
4 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
40 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: 40 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.

questions.question: Assume that a 4 percent increase in income results in a 2 percent increase in the quantity demanded of a good. The income elasticity of demand for the good is
options: negative, and the good is an inferior good.
negative, and the good is a normal good.
positive, and the good is a normal good.
positive, and the good is an inferior good.
questions.answer: positive, and the good is a normal good.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 0.4, then a 10 percent increase in price results in a
options: 0.4 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
2.5 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
4 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
40 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: 4 percent decrease in the quantity demanded.

questions.question: Assume that a 4 percent decrease in income results in a 6 percent increase in the quantity demanded of a good. The income elasticity of demand for the good is
options: negative, and the good is an inferior good.
negative, and the good is a normal good.
positive, and the good is an inferior good.
positive, and the good is a normal good.
questions.answer: negative, and the good is an inferior good.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 0.25, then a 20 percent decrease in price results in a
options: 0.0125 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
4 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
5 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
80 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: 5 percent increase in the quantity demanded.

questions.question: Reta's income elasticity of demand for steak dinners is 1.50. All else equal, this means that if her income increases by 20 percent, she will buy
options: 150 percent more steak dinners.
50 percent more steak dinners.
30 percent more steak dinners.
20 percent more steak dinners.
questions.answer: 30 percent more steak dinners.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 1.5, then a 3 percent decrease in price results in a
options: 0.5 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
2 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
4.5 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
5 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: 4.5 percent increase in the quantity demanded.

questions.question: When her income increased from $10,000 to $20,000, Heather's consumption of macaroni decreased from 10 pounds to 5 pounds and her consumption of soy-burgers increased from 2 pounds to 4 pounds. We can conclude that for Heather, macaroni
options: and soy-burgers are both normal goods with income elasticities equal to 1.
is an inferior good and soy-burgers are normal goods; both have income elasticities of 1.
is an inferior good with an income elasticity of -1 and soy-burgers are normal goods with an income elasticity of 1.
and soy-burgers are both inferior goods with income elasticities equal to -1.
questions.answer: is an inferior good with an income elasticity of -1 and soy-burgers are normal goods with an income elasticity of 1.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 0.2, then a 3 percent decrease in price results in a
options: 0.6 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
1.5 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
2 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
6 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: 0.6 percent increase in the quantity demanded.

questions.question: Which of the following should be held constant when calculating an income elasticity of demand?
options: the quantity of the good demanded
the price of the good
income
All of the above should be held constant.
questions.answer: the price of the good

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 1, then a 3 percent decrease in price results in a
options: 0.1 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
1 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
3 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
4 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: 3 percent increase in the quantity demanded.

questions.question: Which of the following should be held constant when calculating an income elasticity of demand?
options: the price of the good
prices of related goods
tastes
All of the above should be held constant.
questions.answer: All of the above should be held constant.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 4, then a 12 percent decrease in price results in a
options: 0.33 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
3 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
30 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
48 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: 48 percent increase in the quantity demanded.

questions.question: Food and clothing tend to have
options: small income elasticities because consumers, regardless of their incomes, choose to buy relatively constant quantities of these goods.
small income elasticities because consumers buy proportionately more of both goods at higher income levels than they buy at low income levels.
large income elasticities because they are necessities.
large income elasticities because they are relatively inexpensive.
questions.answer: small income elasticities because consumers, regardless of their incomes, choose to buy relatively constant quantities of these goods.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 0.8, then which of the following events is consistent with a 4 percent decrease in the quantity of the good demanded?
options: a 0.2 percent increase in the price of the good
a 3.2 percent increase in the price of the good
a 4.8 percent increase in the price of the good
a 5 percent increase in the price of the good
questions.answer: a 5 percent increase in the price of the good

questions.question: The income elasticity of demand for caviar tends to be
options: high because caviar is relatively expensive.
low because caviar is packaged in small containers.
high because buyers generally feel that they can do without it.
low because it is almost always in short supply.
questions.answer: high because buyers generally feel that they can do without it.

questions.question: For a particular good, a 2 percent increase in price causes a 12 percent decrease in quantity demanded. Which of the following statements is most likely applicable to this good?
options: There are no close substitutes for this good.
The good is a luxury.
The market for the good is broadly defined.
The relevant time horizon is short.
questions.answer: The good is a luxury.

questions.question: While in college, John and Bethany each buy five packages of mac-n-cheese per week. After they graduate and have full-time jobs, John buys six packages per week, but Bethany buys only two packages per week. When looking at income elasticity of demand for mac-n-cheese, John's
options: is negative, and Bethany's is positive.
is positive, and Bethany's is negative.
is zero, and Bethany's approaches infinity.
approaches infinity, and Bethany's is zero.
questions.answer: is positive, and Bethany's is negative.

questions.question: For a particular good, a 5 percent increase in price causes a 15 percent decrease in quantity demanded. Which of the following statements is most likely applicable to this good?
options: There are many substitutes for this good.
The good is a necessity.
The market for the good is broadly defined.
The relevant time horizon is short.
questions.answer: There are many substitutes for this good.

questions.question: Charles purchases 20 basketball tickets per year when his annual income is $50,000 and 25 basketball tickets when his annual income is $60,000. Charles's income elasticity of demand for basketball ticket is
options: 0.82, and basketball tickets are a normal good.
0.82, and basketball tickets are an inferior good.
1.22, and basketball tickets are a normal good.
1.22, and basketball tickets are an inferior good.
questions.answer: 1.22, and basketball tickets are a normal good.

questions.question: For a particular good, a 10 percent increase in price causes a 5 percent decrease in quantity demanded. Which of the following statements is most likely applicable to this good?
options: There are many close substitutes for this good.
The good is a necessity.
The market for the good is narrowly defined.
The relevant time horizon is long.
questions.answer: The good is a necessity.

questions.question: Tyler purchases 5 pounds of hot dogs per month when his monthly income is $2,000 and 4 pounds of hot dogs per month when his monthly income is $2,200. Tyler's income elasticity of demand for hot dogs is
options: 2.33, and hot dogs are a normal good.
-2.33, and hot dogs are an inferior good.
0.43, and hot dogs are a normal good.
-0.43, and hot dogs are an inferior good.
questions.answer: -2.33, and hot dogs are an inferior good.

questions.question: For a particular good, a 10 percent increase in price causes a 15 percent decrease in quantity demanded. Which of the following statements is most likely applicable to this good?
options: There are no close substitutes for this good.
The good is a necessity.
The market for the good is broadly defined.
The relevant time horizon is long.
questions.answer: The relevant time horizon is long.

questions.question: Suppose goods A and B are substitutes for each other. We would expect the cross-price elasticity between these two goods to be
options: positive.
negative.
either positive or negative. It depends whether A and B are normal goods or inferior goods.
either positive or negative. It depends whether the current price level is on the elastic or inelastic portion of the demand curve.
questions.answer: positive.

questions.question: For a particular good, a 5 percent increase in price causes a 2 percent decrease in quantity demanded. Which of the following statements is most likely applicable to this good?
options: There are many close substitutes for this good.
The good is a luxury.
The market for the good is broadly defined.
The relevant time horizon is long.
questions.answer: The market for the good is broadly defined.

questions.question: Last month, sellers of good Y took in $100 in total revenue on sales of 50 units of good Y. This month sellers of good Y raised their price and took in $120 in total revenue on sales of 40 units of good Y. At the same time, the price of good X stayed the same, but sales of good X increased from 20 units to 40 units. We can conclude that goods X and Y are
options: substitutes, and have a cross-price elasticity of 0.60.
complements, and have a cross-price elasticity of 0.60.
substitutes, and have a cross-price elasticity of 1.67.
complements, and have a cross-price elasticity of 1.67.
questions.answer: substitutes, and have a cross-price elasticity of 1.67.

questions.question: For a particular good, a 12 percent increase in price causes a 3 percent decrease in quantity demanded. Which of the following statements is most likely applicable to this good?
options: There are many substitutes for this good.
The good is a necessity.
The market for the good is narrowly defined.
The relevant time horizon is long.
questions.answer: The good is a necessity.

questions.question: Which of the following could be the cross-price elasticity of demand for two goods that are complements?
For a particular good, a 3 percent increase in price causes a 10 percent decrease in quantity demanded. Which of the following statements is most likely applicable to this good?
options: The relevant time horizon is short.
The good is a necessity.
The market for the good is broadly defined.
There are many close substitutes for this good.
questions.answer: There are many close substitutes for this good.

questions.question: Suppose that when the price of good X falls from $10 to $8, the quantity demanded of good Y rises from 20 units to 25 units. Using the midpoint method, the cross-price elasticity of demand is
options: -1.0, and X and Y are complements.
-1.0, and X and Y are substitutes.
1.0, and X and Y are complements.
1.0, and X and Y are substitutes.
questions.answer: -1.0, and X and Y are complements.

questions.question: For a particular good, a 10 percent increase in price causes a 3 percent decrease in quantity demanded. Which of the following statements is most likely applicable to this good?
options: The relevant time horizon is short.
The good is a luxury.
The market for the good is narrowly defined.
There are many close substitutes for this good.
questions.answer: The relevant time horizon is short.

questions.question: Which of the following expressions represents a cross-price elasticity of demand?
options: percentage change in quantity demanded of bread divided by percentage change in quantity supplied of bread
percentage change in quantity demanded of bread divided by percentage change in price of butter
percentage change in price of bread divided by percentage change in quantity demanded of bread
percentage change in quantity demanded of bread divided by percentage change in income
questions.answer: percentage change in quantity demanded of bread divided by percentage change in price of butter

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand for a good is 6, then a 3 percent decrease in price results in
options: a 20 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
an 18 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
a 2 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
a 1.8 percent increase in the quantity demanded.
questions.answer: an 18 percent increase in the quantity demanded.

questions.question: Cross-price elasticity of demand measures how
options: the price of one good changes in response to a change in the price of another good.
the quantity demanded of one good changes in response to a change in the quantity demanded of another good.
the quantity demanded of one good changes in response to a change in the price of another good.
strongly normal or inferior a good is.
questions.answer: the quantity demanded of one good changes in response to a change in the price of another good.

questions.question: Elasticity of demand is closely related to the slope of the demand curve. The more responsive buyers are to a change in price, the
options: steeper the demand curve will be.
flatter the demand curve will be.
further to the right the demand curve will sit.
closer to the vertical axis the demand curve will sit.
questions.answer: flatter the demand curve will be.

questions.question: The cross-price elasticity of demand can tell us whether goods are
options: normal or inferior.
elastic or inelastic.
luxuries or necessities.
complements or substitutes.
questions.answer: complements or substitutes.

questions.question: Elasticity of demand is closely related to the slope of the demand curve. The less responsive buyers are to a change in price, the
options: steeper the demand curve will be.
flatter the demand curve will be.
further to the right the demand curve will sit.
closer to the vertical axis the demand curve will sit.
questions.answer: steeper the demand curve will be.

questions.question: If the cross-price elasticity of two goods is negative, then the two goods are
options: necessities.
complements.
normal goods.
inferior goods.
questions.answer: complements.

questions.question: The flatter the demand curve through a given point, the
options: greater the price elasticity of demand at that point.
smaller the price elasticity of demand at that point.
closer the price elasticity of demand will be to the slope of the curve.
greater the absolute value of the change in total revenue when there is a movement from that point upward and to the left along the demand curve.
questions.answer: greater the price elasticity of demand at that point.

questions.question: If the cross-price elasticity of two goods is positive, then the two goods are
options: substitutes.
complements.
normal goods.
inferior goods.
questions.answer: substitutes.

questions.question: The smaller the price elasticity of demand, the
options: steeper the demand curve will be through a given point.
flatter the demand curve will be through a given point.
more strongly buyers respond to a change in price between any two prices P1 and P2.
smaller the decrease in equilibrium price when the supply curve shifts rightward from S1 to S2.
questions.answer: steeper the demand curve will be through a given point.

questions.question: Suppose the cross-price elasticity of demand between hot dogs and mustard is -2.00. This implies that a 20 percent increase in the price of hot dogs will cause the quantity of mustard purchased to
options: fall by 200 percent.
fall by 40 percent.
rise by 200 percent.
rise by 40 percent.
questions.answer: fall by 40 percent.

questions.question: As we move downward and to the right along a linear, downward-sloping demand curve,
options: both slope and elasticity remain constant.
slope changes but elasticity remains constant.
both slope and elasticity change.
slope remains constant but elasticity changes.
questions.answer: slope remains constant but elasticity changes.

questions.question: If two goods are substitutes, their cross-price elasticity will be
options: positive.
negative.
zero.
equal to the difference between the income elasticities of demand for the two goods.
questions.answer: positive.

questions.question: The difference between slope and elasticity is that slope
options: is a ratio of two changes, and elasticity is a ratio of two percentage changes.
is a ratio of two percentage changes, and elasticity is a ratio of two changes.
measures changes in quantity demanded more accurately than elasticity.
none of the above; there is no difference between slope and elasticity.
questions.answer: is a ratio of two changes, and elasticity is a ratio of two percentage changes.

questions.question: If two goods are complements, their cross-price elasticity will be
options: positive.
negative.
zero.
equal to the difference between the income elasticities of demand for the two goods.
questions.answer: negative.

questions.question: Goods with many close substitutes tend to have
options: more elastic demands.
less elastic demands.
price elasticities of demand that are unit elastic.
income elasticities of demand that are negative.
questions.answer: more elastic demands.

questions.question: For which pairs of goods is the cross-price elasticity most likely to be positive?
options: peanut butter and jelly
bicycle frames and bicycle tires
pens and pencils
college textbooks and iPods
questions.answer: pens and pencils

questions.question: For a good that is a luxury, demand
options: tends to be inelastic.
tends to be elastic.
has unit elasticity.
cannot be represented by a demand curve in the usual way.
questions.answer: tends to be elastic.

questions.question: For which pairs of goods is the cross-price elasticity most likely to be negative?
options: peanut butter and jelly
automobile tires and coffee
pens and pencils
paperback novels and electronic books for e-readers
questions.answer: peanut butter and jelly

questions.question: The demand for Godiva pumpkin truffles is likely quite elastic because
options: truffles melt easily.
this particular type of chocolate is viewed as a necessity by many chocolate lovers.
the market is broadly defined.
other types of chocolate are good substitutes for this particular flavor.
questions.answer: other types of chocolate are good substitutes for this particular flavor.

questions.question: If the cross-price elasticity of demand for two goods is 1.25, then
options: the two goods are luxuries.
the two goods are substitutes.
one of the goods is normal and the other good is inferior.
the demand for one of the goods conforms to the law of demand, but the demand for the other good violates the law of demand.
questions.answer: the two goods are substitutes.

questions.question: The demand for Hubba Bubba bubble gum is likely
options: elastic because gum is expensive relative to other snacks.
elastic because there are many close substitutes for Hubba Bubba.
elastic because bubble gum is regarded as a necessity by many people.
inelastic because it is consumed quickly, making the relevant time horizon short.
questions.answer: elastic because there are many close substitutes for Hubba Bubba.

questions.question: If the cross-price elasticity of demand for two goods is -4.5, then
options: the two goods are substitutes.
the two goods are complements.
one of the goods is normal while the other good is inferior.
one of the goods is a luxury while the other good is a necessity.
questions.answer: the two goods are complements.

questions.question: A good will have a more elastic demand, the
options: greater the availability of close substitutes.
more broad the definition of the market.
shorter the period of time.
more it is regarded as a necessity.
questions.answer: greater the availability of close substitutes.

questions.question: Sandra purchases 5 pounds of coffee and 10 gallons of milk per month when the price of coffee is $10 per pound. She purchases 6 pounds of coffee and 12 gallons of milk per month when the price of coffee is $8 per pound. Sandra's cross-price elasticity of demand for coffee and milk is
options: 0.82, and they are substitutes.
-0.82, and they are complements.
1.22, and they are substitutes.
-1.22, and they are complements.
questions.answer: -0.82, and they are complements.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
options: The demand for flat-screen computer monitors is more elastic than the demand for monitors in general.
The demand for grandfather clocks is more elastic than the demand for clocks in general.
The demand for cardboard is more elastic over a long period of time than over a short period of time.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: All of the above are correct.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct?
options: The demand for natural gas is more elastic over a short period of time than over a long period of time.
The demand for smoke alarms is more elastic than the demand for Persian rugs.
The demand for bourbon whiskey is more elastic than the demand for alcoholic beverages in general.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: The demand for bourbon whiskey is more elastic than the demand for alcoholic beverages in general.

questions.question: The value of the price elasticity of demand for a good will be relatively large when
options: there are no good substitutes available for the good.
the time period in question is relatively short.
the good is a luxury rather than a necessity.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: the good is a luxury rather than a necessity.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of demand is 1.5, regardless of which two points on the demand curve are used to compute the elasticity, then demand is
options: perfectly inelastic, and the demand curve is vertical.
elastic, and the demand curve is a straight, downward-sloping line.
perfectly elastic, and the demand curve is horizontal.
elastic, and the demand curve is something other than a straight, downward-sloping line.
questions.answer: elastic, and the demand curve is something other than a straight, downward-sloping line.

questions.question: Suppose that quantity demand falls by 30% as a result of a 5% increase in price. The price elasticity of demand for this good is
options: inelastic and equal to 6.
elastic and equal to 6.
inelastic and equal to 0.17.
elastic and equal to 0.17.
questions.answer: elastic and equal to 6.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price elastic demand?
options: clothing
blue jeans
Tommy Hilfiger jeans
All three would have the same elasticity of demand because they are all related.
questions.answer: Tommy Hilfiger jeans

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price elastic demand?
options: ice cream
frozen yogurt
vanilla ice cream
Hagen-Dazs(R) vanilla bean ice cream
questions.answer: Hagen-Dazs(R) vanilla bean ice cream

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price elastic demand?
options: latts
doctor's visits
eggs
natural gas
questions.answer: latts

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price elastic demand?
options: dental floss
milk
salt
diamond earrings
questions.answer: diamond earrings

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price elastic demand?
options: gasoline in the short run
dentist's visits
ice cream
deodorant
questions.answer: ice cream

questions.question: Demand is said to be price elastic if
options: the price of the good responds substantially to changes in demand.
demand shifts substantially when income or the expected future price of the good changes.
buyers do not respond much to changes in the price of the good.
buyers respond substantially to changes in the price of the good.
questions.answer: buyers respond substantially to changes in the price of the good.

questions.question: When quantity demanded responds strongly to changes in price, demand is said to be
options: fluid.
elastic.
dynamic.
highly variable.
questions.answer: elastic.

questions.question: Demand is elastic if the price elasticity of demand is
options: less than 1.
equal to 1.
equal to 0.
greater than 1.
questions.answer: greater than 1.

questions.question: For a good that is a necessity,
options: quantity demanded tends to respond substantially to a change in price.
demand tends to be inelastic.
the law of demand does not apply.
All of the above are correct.
questions.answer: demand tends to be inelastic.

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price inelastic demand?
options: mint-flavored toothpaste
toothpaste
Colgate mint-flavored toothpaste
a generic mint-flavored toothpaste
questions.answer: toothpaste

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price inelastic demand?
options: white chocolate chip with macadamia nut cookies
Mrs. Field's chocolate chip cookies
milk chocolate chip cookies
cookies
questions.answer: cookies

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price inelastic demand?
options: white chocolate chip with macadamia nut cookies
hardback novels
salt
box seats at a major league baseball game
questions.answer: salt

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price inelastic demand?
options: laptop computers
iPod shuffles
designer jeans
college tuition for a junior or senior
questions.answer: college tuition for a junior or senior

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price inelastic demand?
options: strawberry-banana milk shakes
gasoline in the short run
diamond earrings
box seats at a major league baseball game
questions.answer: gasoline in the short run

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price inelastic demand?
options: chocolate
Godiva chocolate
Hershey's chocolate
All three would have the same elasticity of demand because they are all related.
questions.answer: chocolate

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price inelastic demand?
options: camcorders
insulin
apples
devices that remove cores from apples
questions.answer: insulin

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price inelastic demand?
options: athletic shoes
running shoes
Nike running shoes
Nike Shox running shoes
questions.answer: athletic shoes

questions.question: Which of the following is likely to have the most price inelastic demand?
options: latts
filet mignon
Grey Goose(R) vodka
milk
questions.answer: milk

questions.question: For a good that is a necessity, demand
options: tends to be inelastic.
tends to be elastic.
has unit elasticity.
cannot be represented by a demand curve in the usual way.
questions.answer: tends to be inelastic.

questions.question: A person who takes a prescription drug to control high cholesterol most likely has a demand for that drug that is
options: inelastic.
unit elastic.
elastic.
highly responsive to changes in income.
questions.answer: inelastic.

questions.question: There are very few, if any, good substitutes for motor oil. Therefore, the
options: demand for motor oil would tend to be inelastic.
demand for motor oil would tend to be elastic.
demand for motor oil would tend to respond strongly to changes in prices of other goods.
supply of motor oil would tend to respond strongly to changes in people's tastes for large cars relative to their tastes for small cars.
questions.answer: demand for motor oil would tend to be inelastic.

questions.question: A good will have a more inelastic demand, the
options: greater the availability of close substitutes.
broader the definition of the market.
longer the period of time.
more it is regarded as a luxury.
questions.answer: broader the definition of the market.

questions.question: Other things equal, the demand for a good tends to be more inelastic, the
options: fewer the available substitutes.
longer the time period considered.
more the good is considered a luxury good.
more narrowly defined is the market for the good.
questions.answer: fewer the available substitutes.

questions.question: Suppose that quantity demand rises by 10% as a result of a 15% decrease in price. The price elasticity of demand for this good is
options: inelastic and equal to 0.67.
elastic and equal to 0.67.
inelastic and equal to 1.50.
elastic and equal to 1.50.
questions.answer: inelastic and equal to 0.67.

questions.question: There are very few, if any, good substitutes for automotive tires. Therefore, the demand for automotive tires would tend to be
options: elastic.
unit elastic.
inelastic.
highly responsive to changes in income as well as changes in prices.
questions.answer: inelastic.

questions.question: Demand is said to be inelastic if
options: buyers respond substantially to changes in the price of the good.
demand shifts only slightly when the price of the good changes.
the quantity demanded changes only slightly when the price of the good changes.
the price of the good responds only slightly to changes in demand.
questions.answer: the quantity demanded changes only slightly when the price of the good changes.

questions.question: If demand is price inelastic, then
options: buyers do not respond much to a change in price.
buyers respond substantially to a change in price, but the response is very slow.
buyers do not alter their quantities demanded much in response to advertising, fads, or general changes in tastes.
the demand curve is very flat.
questions.answer: buyers do not respond much to a change in price.

questions.question: If the quantity demanded of a certain good responds only slightly to a change in the price of the good, then the
options: demand for the good is said to be elastic.
demand for the good is said to be inelastic.
law of demand does not apply to the good.
demand curve for the good shifts only slightly in response to a change in price.
questions.answer: demand for the good is said to be inelastic.

questions.question: Demand is inelastic if the price elasticity of demand is
options: less than 1.
equal to 1.
greater than 1.
equal to 0.
questions.answer: less than 1.

questions.question: Demand is said to be inelastic if the
options: quantity demanded changes proportionately more than price.
price changes proportionately more than income.
quantity demanded changes proportionately less than price.
quantity demanded changes proportionately the same as price.
questions.answer: quantity demanded changes proportionately less than price.

questions.question: When the price of bubble gum is $0.50, the quantity demanded is 400 packs per day. When the price falls to $0.40, the quantity demanded increases to 600. Given this information and using the midpoint method, we know that the demand for bubble gum is
options: inelastic.
elastic.
unit elastic.
perfectly inelastic.
questions.answer: elastic.

questions.question: The midpoint method is used to compute elasticity because it
options: automatically computes a positive number instead of a negative number.
results in an elasticity that is the same as the slope of the demand curve.
gives the same answer regardless of the direction of change.
automatically rounds quantities to the nearest whole unit.
questions.answer: gives the same answer regardless of the direction of change.

questions.question: Suppose the price of potato chips decreases from $1.45 to $1.25 and, as a result, the quantity of potato chips demanded increases from 2,000 to 2,200. Using the midpoint method, the price elasticity of demand for potato chips in the given price range is

Using the midpoint method, the price elasticity of demand for a good is computed to be approximately 0.75. Which of the following events is consistent with a 10 percent decrease in the quantity of the good demanded?
options: a 7.5 increase in the price of the good
a 13.33 percent increase in the price of the good
an increase in the price of the good from $7.50 to $10
an increase in the price of the good from $10 to $17.50
questions.answer: a 13.33 percent increase in the price of the good

questions.question: Using the midpoint method, the price elasticity of demand for a good is computed to be approximately 2. Which of the following events is consistent with a 0.1 percent increase in the price of the good?
options: The quantity of the good demanded decreases from 250 to 150.
The quantity of the good demanded decreases from 200 to 100.
The quantity of the good demanded decreases by 0.05 percent.
The quantity of the good demanded decreases by 0.2 percent.
questions.answer: The quantity of the good demanded decreases by 0.2 percent.

questions.question: Studies indicate that the price elasticity of demand for cigarettes is about 0.4. A government policy aimed at reducing smoking changed the price of a pack of cigarettes from $2 to $6. According to the midpoint method, the government policy should have reduced smoking by

When the price of a good is $5, the quantity demanded is 100 units per month; when the price is $7, the quantity demanded is 80 units per month. Using the midpoint method, the price elasticity of demand is about

When the price of a good is $5, the quantity demanded is 120 units per month; when the price is $7, the quantity demanded is 100 units per month. Using the midpoint method, the price elasticity of demand is about

When the price of a bracelet was $25 each, the jewelry shop sold 20 per month. When it raised the price to $35 each, it sold 14 per month. Using the midpoint method, the price elasticity of demand for bracelets is about
Which of the following expressions is valid for the price elasticity of demand? . Price elasticity of demand = . Price elasticity of demand = .
options: Price elasticity of demand = .
Price elasticity of demand =
questions.answer: Price elasticity of demand =

questions.question: Which of the following expressions can be used to compute the price elasticity of demand?  Price elasticity of demand = . Price elasticity of demand =  . Price elasticity of demand =  .
options: Price elasticity of demand =  .
questions.answer: C

questions.question: Suppose that 50 ice cream cones are demanded at a particular price. If the price of ice cream cones rises from that price by 4 percent, the number of ice cream cones demanded falls to 46. Using the midpoint approach to calculate the price elasticity of demand, it follows that the
options: demand for ice cream cones in this price range is elastic.
demand for ice cream cones in this price range is inelastic.
demand for ice cream cones in this price range is unit elastic.
price elasticity of demand for ice cream cones in this price range is 0.
questions.answer: demand for ice cream cones in this price range is elastic.

questions.question: When the price of used cds is $4, Daphne buys five per month. When the price is $3, she buys nine per month. Daphne's demand for used cds is
options: elastic, and her demand curve would be relatively flat.
elastic, and her demand curve would be relatively steep.
inelastic, and her demand curve would be relatively flat.
inelastic, and her demand curve would be relatively steep.
questions.answer: elastic, and her demand curve would be relatively flat.

questions.question: The midpoint method for calculating elasticities is convenient in that it allows us to
options: ignore the percentage change in quantity demanded and instead focus entirely on the percentage change in price.
calculate the same value for the elasticity, regardless of whether the price increases or decreases.
assume that sellers' total revenue stays constant when the price changes.
restrict all elasticity values to between 0 and 1.
questions.answer: calculate the same value for the elasticity, regardless of whether the price increases or decreases.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-2. Using the midpoint method, if the price falls from $80 to $60, the absolute value of the price elasticity of demand is
Refer to Table 5-2. Using the midpoint method, if the price falls from $60 to $40, the absolute value of the price elasticity of demand is
Refer to Table 5-2. Using the midpoint method, if the price falls from $40 to $20, the absolute value of the price elasticity of demand is
Refer to Table 5-2. Using the midpoint method, if the price falls from $80 to $60, the price elasticity of demand is
options: zero.
unit elastic.
inelastic.
elastic.
questions.answer: elastic.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-2. Using the midpoint method, if the price falls from $60 to $40, the price elasticity of demand is
options: zero.
inelastic.
unit elastic.
elastic.
questions.answer: unit elastic.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-2. Using the midpoint method, if the price falls from $40 to $20, the price elasticity of demand is
options: zero.
inelastic.
unit elastic.
elastic.
questions.answer: inelastic.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-3. Using the midpoint method, what is the price elasticity of demand when price rises from $9 to $12?
Refer to Table 5-3. Using the midpoint method, when price rises from $6 to $9, the price elasticity of demand is
Refer to Table 5-3. Using the midpoint method, when price falls from $6 to $3, the price elasticity of demand is
Refer to Table 5-4. As price rises from $10 to $12, the price elasticity of demand using the midpoint method is approximately
Refer to Table 5-4. Demand is unit elastic when quantity demanded changes from
options: 9 to 8.
8 to 7.
There is not enough information given to determine the correct answer.
questions.answer: 8 to 7.

questions.question: Refer to Table 5-4. When price is between $10 and $14, demand is
options: elastic.
unit elastic.
inelastic.
There is not enough information given to determine whether demand is elastic, unit elastic, or inelastic.
questions.answer: inelastic.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 5-1. Between point A and point B, price elasticity of demand is equal to
Refer to Figure 5-1. Between point A and point B, the slope is equal to
options: -1/4, and the price elasticity of demand is equal to 2/3.
-1/4, and the price elasticity of demand is equal to 3/2.
-3/2, and the price elasticity of demand is equal to 1/4.
-2/3, and the price elasticity of demand is equal to 3/2.
questions.answer: -1/4, and the price elasticity of demand is equal to 3/2.

questions.question: Refer to Figure 5-1. Between point A and point B on the graph, demand is
options: perfectly elastic.
inelastic.
unit elastic.
elastic, but not perfectly elastic.
questions.answer: elastic, but not perfectly elastic.

questions.question: Suppose demand is perfectly elastic, and the supply of the good in question decreases. As a result,
options: the equilibrium quantity decreases, and the equilibrium price is unchanged.
the equilibrium price increases, and the equilibrium quantity is unchanged.
the equilibrium quantity and the equilibrium price both are unchanged.
buyers' total expenditure on the good is unchanged.
questions.answer: the equilibrium quantity decreases, and the equilibrium price is unchanged.

questions.question: A perfectly elastic demand implies that
options: buyers will not respond to any change in price.
any rise in price above that represented by the demand curve will result in a quantity demanded of zero.
quantity demanded and price change by the same percent as we move along the demand curve.
price will rise by an infinite amount when there is a change in quantity demanded.
questions.answer: any rise in price above that represented by the demand curve will result in a quantity demanded of zero.

questions.question: The case of perfectly elastic demand is illustrated by a demand curve that is
options: vertical.
horizontal.
downward-sloping but relatively steep.
downward-sloping but relatively flat.
questions.answer: horizontal.

questions.question: When small changes in price lead to infinite changes in quantity demanded, demand is perfectly
options: elastic, and the demand curve will be horizontal.
inelastic, and the demand curve will be horizontal.
elastic, and the demand curve will be vertical.
inelastic, and the demand curve will be vertical.
questions.answer: elastic, and the demand curve will be horizontal.

questions.question: For a horizontal demand curve,
options: the slope is undefined, and the price elasticity of demand is equal to 0.
the slope is equal to 0, and the price elasticity of demand is undefined.
both the slope and price elasticity of demand are undefined.
both the slope and price elasticity of demand are equal to 0.
questions.answer: the slope is equal to 0, and the price elasticity of demand is undefined.

questions.question: Suppose demand is perfectly inelastic, and the supply of the good in question decreases. As a result,
options: the equilibrium quantity decreases, and the equilibrium price is unchanged.
the equilibrium price increases, and the equilibrium quantity is unchanged.
the equilibrium quantity and the equilibrium price both are unchanged.
buyers' total expenditure on the good is unchanged.
questions.answer: the equilibrium price increases, and the equilibrium quantity is unchanged.

questions.question: In the case of perfectly inelastic demand,
options: the change in quantity demanded equals the change in price.
the percentage change in quantity demanded equals the percentage change in price.
infinitely-large changes in quantity demanded result from very small changes in the price.
quantity demanded stays the same whenever price changes.
questions.answer: quantity demanded stays the same whenever price changes.

questions.question: When demand is perfectly inelastic, the demand curve will be
options: negatively sloped, because buyers decrease their purchases when the price rises.
vertical, because buyers purchase the same amount as before whenever the price rises or falls.
positively sloped, because buyers increase their purchases when price rises.
positively sloped, because buyers increase their total expenditures when price rises.
questions.answer: vertical, because buyers purchase the same amount as before whenever the price rises or falls.

questions.question: When demand is perfectly inelastic, the price elasticity of demand
options: is zero, and the demand curve is vertical.
is zero, and the demand curve is horizontal.
approaches infinity, and the demand curve is vertical.

questions.question: A key determinant of the price elasticity of supply is the

questions.answer: length of the time period.

questions.answer: the ability of sellers to change the amount of the good they produce.

questions.answer: demand for wheat is elastic.

questions.answer: the quantity supplied responds to changes in the price of the good.

questions.answer: decrease the total revenue of wheat farmers.

questions.answer: wheat farmers would experience an increase in their total revenue.

questions.answer: a constant slope and a changing price elasticity of supply.

questions.answer: reduce the number of acres on which they plant corn.

The number of firms in a market tends to be more variable over long periods of time than over short periods of time.

questions.answer: The number of firms in a market tends to be more variable over long periods of time than over short periods of time.

questions.answer: the relevant time period is long rather than short.

0.88 when the price increased from $2.00 to $2.50 and 1.08 when the price increased from $2.50 to $3.00.

1.50 when the price increased from $2.00 to $2.50 and 1.18 when the price increased from $2.50 to $3.00.
questions.answer: 1.42 when the price increased from $2.00 to $2.50 and 1.32 when the price increased from $2.50 to $3.00.

1.27 when the price increased from $1.00 to $1.50 and 1.19 when the price increased from $1.50 to $2.00.
0.79 when the price increased from $1.00 to $1.50 and 1.19 when the price increased from $1.50 to $2.00.
1.27 when the price increased from $1.00 to $1.50 and 0.84 when the price increased from $1.50 to $2.00.
questions.answer: 0.79 when the price increased from $1.00 to $1.50 and 0.84 when the price increased from $1.50 to $2.00.

questions.question: The supply of a good will be more elastic, the
options: more the good is considered a luxury.
broader is the definition of the market for the good.
larger the number of close substitutes for the good.
longer the time period being considered.
questions.answer: longer the time period being considered.

questions.question: In the long run, the quantity supplied of most goods
options: will increase in almost all cases, regardless of what happens to price.
cannot respond at all to a change in price.
can respond to a change in price, but the change is almost always inconsequential.
can respond substantially to a change in price.
questions.answer: can respond substantially to a change in price.

questions.question: When a supply curve is relatively flat, the
options: sellers are not at all responsive to a change in price.
equilibrium price changes substantially when the demand for the good changes.
supply is relatively elastic.
supply is relatively inelastic.
questions.answer: supply is relatively elastic.

questions.question: When a supply curve is relatively flat,
options: sellers are not very responsive to changes in price.
supply is relatively inelastic.
supply is relatively elastic.
Both a and b are correct.
questions.answer: supply is relatively elastic.

questions.question: As price elasticity of supply increases, the supply curve
options: becomes flatter.
becomes steeper.
becomes downward sloping.
shifts to the right.
questions.answer: becomes flatter.

questions.question: If a 25% change in price results in a 40% change in quantity supplied, then the price elasticity of supply is about
options: 0.63, and supply is elastic.
0.63, and supply is inelastic.
1.60, and supply is elastic.
1.60, and supply is inelastic.
questions.answer: 1.60, and supply is elastic.

questions.question: If a 15% change in price results in a 20% change in quantity supplied, then the price elasticity of supply is about
options: 1.33, and supply is elastic.
1.33, and supply is inelastic.
0.75, and supply is elastic.
0.75, and supply is inelastic.
questions.answer: 1.33, and supply is elastic.

questions.question: If the quantity supplied responds only slightly to changes in price, then
options: supply is said to be elastic.
supply is said to be inelastic.
an increase in price will not shift the supply curve very much.
even a large decrease in demand will change the equilibrium price only slightly.
questions.answer: supply is said to be inelastic.

questions.question: Frequently, in the short run, the quantity supplied of a good is
options: impossible, or nearly impossible, to measure.
not very responsive to price changes.
determined by the quantity demanded of the good.
determined by psychological forces and other non-economic forces.
questions.answer: not very responsive to price changes.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of supply for wheat is less than 1, then the supply of wheat is
options: inelastic.
elastic.
unit elastic.
quite sensitive to changes in income.
questions.answer: inelastic.

questions.question: If a 40% change in price results in a 25% change in quantity supplied, then the price elasticity of supply is about
options: 0.63, and supply is elastic.
0.63, and supply is inelastic.
1.60, and supply is elastic.
1.60, and supply is inelastic.
questions.answer: 0.63, and supply is inelastic.

questions.question: If a 30 percent change in price causes a 15 percent change in quantity supplied, then the price elasticity of supply is about
options: 0.5, and supply is elastic.
0.5, and supply is inelastic.
2, and supply is inelastic.
2, and supply is elastic.
questions.answer: 0.5, and supply is inelastic.

questions.question: If a 20% change in price results in a 15% change in quantity supplied, then the price elasticity of supply is about
options: 1.33, and supply is elastic.
1.33, and supply is inelastic.
0.75, and supply is elastic.
0.75, and supply is inelastic.
questions.answer: 0.75, and supply is inelastic.

questions.question: If sellers respond to very small changes in price by adjusting their quantity supplied by extremely large amounts, the price elasticity of supply approaches
options: zero, and the supply curve is horizontal.
zero, and the supply curve is vertical.
infinity, and the supply curve is horizontal.
infinity, and the supply curve is vertical.
questions.answer: infinity, and the supply curve is horizontal.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is valid when supply is perfectly elastic at a price of $4?
options: The elasticity of supply approaches infinity.
The supply curve is vertical.
At a price below $4, quantity supplied is infinite.
At a price above $4, quantity supplied is zero.
questions.answer: The elasticity of supply approaches infinity.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not valid when supply is perfectly elastic?
options: The elasticity of supply approaches infinity.
The supply curve is horizontal.
Very small changes in price lead to very large changes in quantity supplied.
The time period under consideration is more likely a short period rather than a long period.
questions.answer: The time period under consideration is more likely a short period rather than a long period.

questions.question: When supply is perfectly elastic, the value of the price elasticity of supply is
options: greater than 0 and less than 1.
infinity.
questions.answer: infinity.

questions.question: As the price elasticity of supply approaches infinity, very small changes in price lead to
options: very large changes in quantity supplied.
very small changes in quantity supplied.
no change in quantity supplied.
None of the above is correct.
questions.answer: very large changes in quantity supplied.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of supply for a good is equal to infinity, then the
options: supply curve is vertical.
supply curve is horizontal.
supply curve also has a slope equal to infinity.
quantity supplied is constant regardless of the price.
questions.answer: supply curve is horizontal.

questions.question: A manufacturer produces 1,000 units, regardless of the market price. For this firm, the price elasticity of supply is
options: infinity.
zero.
one.
negative one.
questions.answer: zero.

questions.question: If sellers do not adjust their quantity supplied at all in response to a change in price, the price elasticity of supply is
options: zero, and the supply curve is horizontal.
zero, and the supply curve is vertical.
infinity, and the supply curve is horizontal.
infinity, and the supply curve is vertical.
questions.answer: zero, and the supply curve is vertical.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is valid when the market supply curve is vertical?
options: Market quantity supplied does not change when the price changes.
Supply is perfectly elastic.
An increase in market demand will increase the equilibrium quantity.
An increase in market demand will not increase the equilibrium price.
questions.answer: Market quantity supplied does not change when the price changes.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not valid when the market supply curve is vertical?
options: Market quantity supplied does not change when the price changes.
Supply is perfectly inelastic.
An increase in market demand will increase the equilibrium quantity.
An increase in market demand will increase the equilibrium price.
questions.answer: An increase in market demand will increase the equilibrium quantity.

questions.question: If the quantity supplied is the same regardless of price, then supply is
options: elastic.
perfectly elastic.
perfectly inelastic.
inelastic.
questions.answer: perfectly inelastic.

questions.question: If sellers do not adjust their quantities supplied at all in response to a change in price,
options: advances in technology must be prevalent.
the time period under consideration must be very long.
supply is perfectly elastic.
supply is perfectly inelastic.
questions.answer: supply is perfectly inelastic.

questions.question: If the price elasticity of supply is zero, then
options: supply is more elastic than it is in any other case.
the supply curve is horizontal.
the quantity supplied is the same, regardless of price.
a change in demand will cause a relatively small change in the equilibrium price.
questions.answer: the quantity supplied is the same, regardless of price.
